qas.question: What is the usual source of heat for boiling water in the steam engine?
Aside from firebox, what is another name for the space in which combustible material is burned in the engine?
Along with nuclear, geothermal and internal combustion engine waste heat, what sort of energy might supply the heat for a steam engine?
What type of heating element is often used in toy steam engines?
What is the usual source of heat for boiling water in the industrial process?
What, aside from firebox, is another name for the space in which combustible material is burned in the electric heating element?
What type of heating element is often used in toy chamber engines?
What sort of energy, along with nuclear, geothermal, and internal combustion waste heat, might supply the heat for a firebox?
What type of heating element is often used in closed space engines?

context: The heat required for boiling the water and supplying the steam can be derived from various sources, most commonly from <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b4_0>burning combustible materials<b4_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> with an appropriate supply of air in a closed space (called variously <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2>combustion chamber<a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>, firebox). In some cases the heat source is a nuclear reactor, geothermal energy, <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><b5_0><b7_0>solar<b7_0/><b5_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> energy or waste heat from an internal combustion engine or industrial process. In the case of model or toy steam engines, the heat source can be an <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><b6_0><b8_0>electric<b8_0/><b6_0/><a3_2/><a3_0/> heating element<a3_1/>.
